events.title: Rochester's Heroism, Bertha's Fiery Demise, and the Hall's Destruction
detailed_summary: Jane sought confirmation from the host that Mr. Rochester had been at Thornfield when the fire erupted.

The host affirmed this, vividly recounting Rochester's heroic actions: he ascended to the attics, then engulfed in flames from above and below, to awaken the servants and personally assist them to safety.
After ensuring the servants' escape, Rochester returned into the inferno to retrieve his wife from her cell.
However, it was then shouted that Bertha was on the roof, where she was seen standing above the battlements, waving her arms and screaming so loudly she could be heard from a mile away.
The host, an eyewitness, described the dramatic scene: Bertha, a large woman with long, dark hair flowing against the backdrop of flames.
He and others witnessed Mr. Rochester make his way onto the roof through a skylight and heard him call out Bertha's name.
As Rochester approached her, Bertha shrieked, leaped from the battlements, and was instantly killed, her body 'smashed on the pavement' below.
Jane, aghast, asked if she was dead, and the host confirmed it unequivocally.
Following Bertha's suicide, the host explained, the house continued to burn until it was reduced to the ground, with only fragments of walls remaining.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Then Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, ma’am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are only some bits of walls standing now.”

events.text_segment:
“Then Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?”
“Yes, indeed was he; and he went up to the attics when all was burning above and below, and got the servants out of their beds and helped them down himself, and went back to get his mad wife out of her cell. And then they called out to him that she was on the roof, where she was standing, waving her arms, above the battlements, and shouting out till they could hear her a mile off: I saw her and heard her with my own eyes. She was a big woman, and had long black hair: we could see it streaming against the flames as she stood. I witnessed, and several more witnessed, Mr. Rochester ascend through the sky-light on to the roof; we heard him call ‘Bertha!’ We saw him approach her; and then, ma’am, she yelled and gave a spring, and the next minute she lay smashed on the pavement.”
“Dead?”
“Dead! Ay, dead as the stones on which her brains and blood were scattered.”
“Good God!”
“You may well say so, ma’am: it was frightful!”
He shuddered.
“And afterwards?” I urged.
“Well, ma’am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are only some bits of walls standing now.”

events.title: The Tragic Price of Rochester's Courage: Blindness and Maiming
detailed_summary: Jane inquired if any other lives had been lost in the devastating fire.
The host responded that no one else perished, but added with a somber tone that it might have been better if others had.

He expressed profound pity for 'Poor Mr. Edward,' noting that while some viewed the tragedy as a divine retribution for Rochester's concealed first marriage and his attempt to marry again, he personally felt compassion for him.
Jane, alarmed by his tone, urgently reconfirmed that Mr. Rochester was indeed alive.
The host affirmed Rochester's survival but ominously stated that many believe he would be better off dead, a remark that sent a chill through Jane.
As Jane pressed for details about Rochester's condition and his current location within England, the host finally delivered the devastating news: 'He is stone-blind.'
Jane, who had harbored fears that Rochester might have descended into madness, found a grim strength to inquire about the cause of this catastrophic injury.
The host attributed Rochester's condition entirely to his bravery and altruism, explaining that he refused to leave the burning house until every other person was safely out.
As Rochester was finally making his escape down the grand staircase, moments after Bertha Rochester had jumped from the battlements, the entire structure collapsed.

He was extricated from the rubble alive but grievously wounded: a fallen beam had offered some protection, yet one of his eyes was destroyed, and one hand was so severely crushed that the surgeon, Mr. Carter, had to amputate it immediately. Subsequently, inflammation developed in his remaining eye, leading to total blindness, rendering him helpless—'blind and a cripple.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Were any other lives lost?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He is now helpless, indeed—blind and a cripple.”

events.text_segment:
“Were any other lives lost?”
“No—perhaps it would have been better if there had.”
“What do you mean?”
“Poor Mr. Edward!” he ejaculated, “I little thought ever to have seen it! Some say it was a just judgment on him for keeping his first marriage secret, and wanting to take another wife while he had one living: but I pity him, for my part.”
“You said he was alive?” I exclaimed.
“Yes, yes: he is alive; but many think he had better be dead.”
“Why? How?” My blood was again running cold. “Where is he?” I demanded. “Is he in England?”
“Ay—ay—he’s in England; he can’t get out of England, I fancy—he’s a fixture now.”
What agony was this! And the man seemed resolved to protract it.
“He is stone-blind,” he said at last. “Yes, he is stone-blind, is Mr. Edward.”
I had dreaded worse. I had dreaded he was mad. I summoned strength to ask what had caused this calamity.
“It was all his own courage, and a body may say, his kindness, in a way, ma’am: he wouldn’t leave the house till every one else was out before him. As he came down the great staircase at last, after Mrs. Rochester had flung herself from the battlements, there was a great crash—all fell. He was taken out from under the ruins, alive, but sadly hurt: a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him partly; but one eye was knocked out, and one hand so crushed that Mr. Carter, the surgeon, had to amputate it directly. The other eye inflamed: he lost the sight of that also. He is now helpless, indeed—blind and a cripple.”

events.title: Learning Rochester's Secluded Whereabouts and Jane's Swift Resolve to Go to Him
detailed_summary: Upon learning of Rochester's catastrophic injuries, Jane immediately asked for his current location.
The host informed her that Mr. Rochester was now residing at Ferndean, a manor-house situated on a farm he owned, approximately thirty miles away, describing the place as 'quite a desolate spot.'
When Jane inquired who was caring for him, the host replied that only old John and his wife were with him, as Rochester refused any other company, adding that he was reportedly 'quite broken down.'
Hearing this, Jane's resolve was instant; she asked if the inn possessed any means of transport.
The host confirmed they had a chaise, which he described as being quite handsome.

Jane then gave decisive instructions for the chaise to be made ready at once, promising to pay double the standard fee to both the innkeeper and the post-boy if she could be driven to Ferndean before nightfall that same day.

events.title: Jane's Arrival at Desolate Ferndean and Sobering Observation of Rochester
detailed_summary: Jane arrives at Ferndean, a remote and gloomy manor, during a dismal evening characterized by a sad sky, cold gale, and penetrating rain.
She finds the house deeply isolated and surrounded by thick, dark woods, matching its inhospitable reputation.
After a challenging final mile on foot and navigating a grass-grown track through the woods, she finally beholds the decaying and desolate-looking manor.
She witnesses Mr. Rochester emerge from the house; initially, she doesn't recognize him without his hat.
Observing him secretly, she notes his physical frame remains strong, but his countenance is marked by desperation and brooding, reminding her of a wronged, captive wild creature.
A mixture of sorrow and a nascent hope to comfort him fills her, yet she chooses not to reveal herself immediately.
She watches as he, evidently blind, attempts to gauge the weather by stretching out his hand and then tries to sense his surroundings, finding only empty space.
John, a servant, approaches to offer Rochester his arm due to an impending heavy shower, but Rochester curtly dismisses him.
Rochester then struggles to navigate by himself and gropes his way back into the house, closing the door behind him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity, moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He groped his way back to the house, and, re-entering it, closed the door.

events.text_segment:
The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity, moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood. I had heard of it before. Mr. Rochester often spoke of it, and sometimes went there. His father had purchased the estate for the sake of the game covers. He would have let the house, but could find no tenant, in consequence of its ineligible and insalubrious site. Ferndean then remained uninhabited and unfurnished, with the exception of some two or three rooms fitted up for the accommodation of the squire when he went there in the season to shoot.
To this house I came just ere dark on an evening marked by the characteristics of sad sky, cold gale, and continued small penetrating rain. The last mile I performed on foot, having dismissed the chaise and driver with the double remuneration I had promised. Even when within a very short distance of the manor-house, you could see nothing of it, so thick and dark grew the timber of the gloomy wood about it. Iron gates between granite pillars showed me where to enter, and passing through them, I found myself at once in the twilight of close-ranked trees. There was a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches. I followed it, expecting soon to reach the dwelling; but it stretched on and on, it wound far and farther: no sign of habitation or grounds was visible.
I thought I had taken a wrong direction and lost my way. The darkness of natural as well as of sylvan dusk gathered over me. I looked round in search of another road. There was none: all was interwoven stem, columnar trunk, dense summer foliage—no opening anywhere.
I proceeded: at last my way opened, the trees thinned a little; presently I beheld a railing, then the house—scarce, by this dim light, distinguishable from the trees; so dank and green were its decaying walls. Entering a portal, fastened only by a latch, I stood amidst a space of enclosed ground, from which the wood swept away in a semicircle. There were no flowers, no garden-beds; only a broad gravel-walk girdling a grass-plat, and this set in the heavy frame of the forest. The house presented two pointed gables in its front; the windows were latticed and narrow: the front door was narrow too, one step led up to it. The whole looked, as the host of the Rochester Arms had said, “quite a desolate spot.” It was as still as a church on a week-day: the pattering rain on the forest leaves was the only sound audible in its vicinage.
“Can there be life here?” I asked.
Yes, life of some kind there was; for I heard a movement—that narrow front-door was unclosing, and some shape was about to issue from the grange.
It opened slowly: a figure came out into the twilight and stood on the step; a man without a hat: he stretched forth his hand as if to feel whether it rained. Dusk as it was, I had recognised him—it was my master, Edward Fairfax Rochester, and no other.
I stayed my step, almost my breath, and stood to watch him—to examine him, myself unseen, and alas! to him invisible. It was a sudden meeting, and one in which rapture was kept well in check by pain. I had no difficulty in restraining my voice from exclamation, my step from hasty advance.
His form was of the same strong and stalwart contour as ever: his port was still erect, his hair was still raven black; nor were his features altered or sunk: not in one year’s space, by any sorrow, could his athletic strength be quelled or his vigorous prime blighted. But in his countenance I saw a change: that looked desperate and brooding—that reminded me of some wronged and fettered wild beast or bird, dangerous to approach in his sullen woe. The caged eagle, whose gold-ringed eyes cruelty has extinguished, might look as looked that sightless Samson.
And, reader, do you think I feared him in his blind ferocity?—if you do, you little know me. A soft hope blent with my sorrow that soon I should dare to drop a kiss on that brow of rock, and on those lips so sternly sealed beneath it: but not yet. I would not accost him yet.
He descended the one step, and advanced slowly and gropingly towards the grass-plat. Where was his daring stride now? Then he paused, as if he knew not which way to turn. He lifted his hand and opened his eyelids; gazed blank, and with a straining effort, on the sky, and toward the amphitheatre of trees: one saw that all to him was void darkness. He stretched his right hand (the left arm, the mutilated one, he kept hidden in his bosom); he seemed to wish by touch to gain an idea of what lay around him: he met but vacancy still; for the trees were some yards off where he stood. He relinquished the endeavour, folded his arms, and stood quiet and mute in the rain, now falling fast on his uncovered head. At this moment John approached him from some quarter.
“Will you take my arm, sir?” he said; “there is a heavy shower coming on: had you not better go in?”
“Let me alone,” was the answer.
John withdrew without having observed me. Mr. Rochester now tried to walk about: vainly,—all was too uncertain. He groped his way back to the house, and, re-entering it, closed the door.

events.title: Jane's Cautious Re-entry and Orchestrated Meeting
detailed_summary: Jane approaches the manor and knocks; Mary, John's wife, opens the door and is visibly startled to see Jane.
Jane reassures Mary, briefly explaining that she learned of the events after her departure from Thornfield and has come to see Mr. Rochester.
She arranges for her trunk to be collected from the turn-pike-house and confirms with Mary that she can be accommodated for the night, deciding to stay.
Upon hearing the parlour-bell, Jane instructs Mary to inform Mr. Rochester that a person wishes to speak with him but to withhold her name.
Mary returns, conveying Rochester's reluctance and his demand for the visitor's name and purpose, noting he generally refuses all visitors.
As Mary prepares a tray with water and candles, she explains that Rochester always has candles brought in at dark, despite his blindness.
Jane, her heart pounding and hands trembling, volunteers to take the tray into the parlour herself.
Mary directs her to the parlour door, opens it for her, and then closes it, leaving Jane to face Rochester.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I now drew near and knocked: John’s wife opened for me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mary opened the door for me, and shut it behind me.

events.text_segment:
I now drew near and knocked: John’s wife opened for me. “Mary,” I said, “how are you?”
She started as if she had seen a ghost: I calmed her. To her hurried “Is it really you, miss, come at this late hour to this lonely place?” I answered by taking her hand; and then I followed her into the kitchen, where John now sat by a good fire. I explained to them, in few words, that I had heard all which had happened since I left Thornfield, and that I was come to see Mr. Rochester. I asked John to go down to the turn-pike-house, where I had dismissed the chaise, and bring my trunk, which I had left there: and then, while I removed my bonnet and shawl, I questioned Mary as to whether I could be accommodated at the Manor House for the night; and finding that arrangements to that effect, though difficult, would not be impossible, I informed her I should stay. Just at this moment the parlour-bell rang.
“When you go in,” said I, “tell your master that a person wishes to speak to him, but do not give my name.”
“I don’t think he will see you,” she answered; “he refuses everybody.”
When she returned, I inquired what he had said.
“You are to send in your name and your business,” she replied. She then proceeded to fill a glass with water, and place it on a tray, together with candles.
“Is that what he rang for?” I asked.
“Yes: he always has candles brought in at dark, though he is blind.”
“Give the tray to me; I will carry it in.”
I took it from her hand: she pointed me out the parlour door. The tray shook as I held it; the water spilt from the glass; my heart struck my ribs loud and fast. Mary opened the door for me, and shut it behind me.

events.title: The Emotional Reunion in the Gloomy Parlour
detailed_summary: Jane enters a gloomy parlour where a small fire burns and Mr. Rochester leans against the mantelpiece; his dog, Pilot, lies nearby.
Pilot instantly recognizes Jane, jumping up with excited yelps and whines, nearly causing her to drop the tray.
Mr. Rochester, hearing the commotion but unable to see its cause, sighs.
He requests water, addressing whom he presumes to be Mary; Jane approaches with the now half-empty glass, Pilot following her excitedly.
Rochester questions the cause of Pilot's excitement. After Jane quiets the dog and he drinks, he asks if it is Mary.
Jane replies that Mary is in the kitchen.
He extends his hand, urgently demanding to know who is present, his sightless eyes making a distressing attempt to see.
Jane offers him more water, and her voice prompts further intense questioning.
She then reveals that Pilot, John, and Mary are aware of her presence, as she has only just arrived that evening.
Rochester exclaims in disbelief, questioning whether he is experiencing a delusion or madness.
Jane firmly reassures him of his sanity.
He desperately implores to be able to touch her, expressing that his heart might stop otherwise.
Jane gently takes his wandering hand, and he immediately recognizes her fingers.
He then pulls her close, recognizing her form and size; her voice finally confirms her identity.
Overcome, he utters her name, a mix of disbelief and profound emotion in his voice.
Jane affirms that it is indeed her and that she has returned to him.
Rochester struggles to accept her presence as real, fearing it is a dream like others he has had, where he has embraced her and felt her love.

events.text_segment:
This parlour looked gloomy: a neglected handful of fire burnt low in the grate; and, leaning over it, with his head supported against the high, old-fashioned mantelpiece, appeared the blind tenant of the room. His old dog, Pilot, lay on one side, removed out of the way, and coiled up as if afraid of being inadvertently trodden upon. Pilot pricked up his ears when I came in: then he jumped up with a yelp and a whine, and bounded towards me: he almost knocked the tray from my hands. I set it on the table; then patted him, and said softly, “Lie down!” Mr. Rochester turned mechanically to see what the commotion was: but as he saw nothing, he returned and sighed.
“Give me the water, Mary,” he said.
I approached him with the now only half-filled glass; Pilot followed me, still excited.
“What is the matter?” he inquired.
“Down, Pilot!” I again said. He checked the water on its way to his lips, and seemed to listen: he drank, and put the glass down. “This is you, Mary, is it not?”
“Mary is in the kitchen,” I answered.
He put out his hand with a quick gesture, but not seeing where I stood, he did not touch me. “Who is this? Who is this?” he demanded, trying, as it seemed, to see with those sightless eyes—unavailing and distressing attempt! “Answer me—speak again!” he ordered, imperiously and aloud.
“Will you have a little more water, sir? I spilt half of what was in the glass,” I said.
“Who is it? What is it? Who speaks?”
“Pilot knows me, and John and Mary know I am here. I came only this evening,” I answered.
“Great God!—what delusion has come over me? What sweet madness has seized me?”
“No delusion—no madness: your mind, sir, is too strong for delusion, your health too sound for frenzy.”
“And where is the speaker? Is it only a voice? Oh! I cannot see, but I must feel, or my heart will stop and my brain burst. Whatever—whoever you are—be perceptible to the touch or I cannot live!”
He groped; I arrested his wandering hand, and prisoned it in both mine.
“Her very fingers!” he cried; “her small, slight fingers! If so there must be more of her.”
The muscular hand broke from my custody; my arm was seized, my shoulder—neck—waist—I was entwined and gathered to him.
“Is it Jane? What is it? This is her shape—this is her size—”
“And this her voice,” I added. “She is all here: her heart, too. God bless you, sir! I am glad to be so near you again.”
“Jane Eyre!—Jane Eyre,” was all he said.
“My dear master,” I answered, “I am Jane Eyre: I have found you out—I am come back to you.”
“In truth?—in the flesh? My living Jane?”
“You touch me, sir,—you hold me, and fast enough: I am not cold like a corpse, nor vacant like air, am I?”
“My living darling! These are certainly her limbs, and these her features; but I cannot be so blest, after all my misery. It is a dream; such dreams as I have had at night when I have clasped her once more to my heart, as I do now; and kissed her, as thus—and felt that she loved me, and trusted that she would not leave me.”

events.title: Jane's Steadfast Commitment and Newfound Independence
detailed_summary: Jane firmly vows that she will never leave Mr. Rochester again, directly addressing his fear that she is merely a transient vision.
She expresses her affection physically, kissing his eyes and brow, which helps him begin to accept the reality of her return.
He anxiously asks if she is truly alive and well, not suffering as an outcast.
Jane proudly informs him that she is now an independent woman.
She explains that her uncle in Madeira has passed away and left her an inheritance of five thousand pounds.
Rochester is visibly astonished and uplifted by this practical and unexpected news, remarking that it brings vitality to his weary heart.
He expresses a concern that her newfound wealth and independence might lead her to seek other companions and not devote herself to him, a blind and lame man.
Jane reassures him of her self-sufficiency and firmly states her intention to remain with him.
She offers to be his neighbor, nurse, housekeeper, and constant companion, promising that he will not be left desolate as long as she lives.
Rochester becomes quiet and thoughtful, his serious and abstracted demeanor causing Jane to worry that she has been overly forward or has transgressed social conventions with her declarations.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Which I never will, sir, from this day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He replied not: he seemed serious—abstracted; he sighed; he half-opened his lips as if to speak: he closed them again.

events.text_segment:
Which I never will, sir, from this day.”
“Never will, says the vision? But I always woke and found it an empty mockery; and I was desolate and abandoned—my life dark, lonely, hopeless—my soul athirst and forbidden to drink—my heart famished and never to be fed. Gentle, soft dream, nestling in my arms now, you will fly, too, as your sisters have all fled before you: but kiss me before you go—embrace me, Jane.”
“There, sir—and there!”’
I pressed my lips to his once brilliant and now rayless eyes—I swept his hair from his brow, and kissed that too. He suddenly seemed to arouse himself: the conviction of the reality of all this seized him.
“It is you—is it, Jane? You are come back to me then?”
“I am.”
“And you do not lie dead in some ditch under some stream? And you are not a pining outcast amongst strangers?”
“No, sir! I am an independent woman now.”
“Independent! What do you mean, Jane?”
“My uncle in Madeira is dead, and he left me five thousand pounds.”
“Ah! this is practical—this is real!” he cried: “I should never dream that. Besides, there is that peculiar voice of hers, so animating and piquant, as well as soft: it cheers my withered heart; it puts life into it.—What, Janet! Are you an independent woman? A rich woman?”
“Quite rich, sir. If you won’t let me live with you, I can build a house of my own close up to your door, and you may come and sit in my parlour when you want company of an evening.”
“But as you are rich, Jane, you have now, no doubt, friends who will look after you, and not suffer you to devote yourself to a blind lameter like me?”
“I told you I am independent, sir, as well as rich: I am my own mistress.”
“And you will stay with me?”
“Certainly—unless you object. I will be your neighbour, your nurse, your housekeeper. I find you lonely: I will be your companion—to read to you, to walk with you, to sit with you, to wait on you, to be eyes and hands to you. Cease to look so melancholy, my dear master; you shall not be left desolate, so long as I live.”
He replied not: he seemed serious—abstracted; he sighed; he half-opened his lips as if to speak: he closed them again.

events.title: Navigating New Dynamics and Rehumanizing Rochester
detailed_summary: Feeling awkward due to Rochester's silence, Jane begins to gently disengage from his embrace, but he quickly pulls her closer.
He passionately confesses his profound need for her, admitting that he cannot relinquish the joy and consolation her presence brings, regardless of how the world might judge him as absurd or selfish.
Jane firmly reiterates her decision to stay with him.

Rochester points out that their understandings of her 'staying' might differ, implying he desires a deeper connection than that of a mere caregiver and questioning whether he should now adopt purely fatherly feelings towards her.
Jane expresses her willingness to fulfill whatever role he prefers, even if it is only as his nurse.
He then melancholically speaks of her youth and the likelihood of her marrying someone else one day, expressing despair over his own diminished state.
Jane, perceiving the root of his insecurity, adopts a more cheerful and proactive demeanor, playfully suggesting he is in need of 'rehumanising' due to his wild appearance.
This prompts Rochester to reveal his mutilated arm, describing it as a truly terrible thing to see, anticipating her revulsion.
Contrary to his expectation, Jane expresses compassion for his injuries and declares that these vulnerabilities make her love him more, not less.
She begins to actively care for him, inquiring about the extent of his remaining vision and insisting that he will have supper, as she herself is hungry and assumes he must be too.

With assistance from Mary, Jane brings more cheer to the room and prepares a comfortable meal for Rochester, her easy and vivacious conversation during and after supper visibly reviving his spirits and warming his demeanor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I felt a little embarrassed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Blind as he was, smiles played over his face, joy dawned on his forehead: his lineaments softened and warmed.

events.text_segment:
I felt a little embarrassed. Perhaps I had too rashly over-leaped conventionalities; and he, like St. John, saw impropriety in my inconsiderateness. I had indeed made my proposal from the idea that he wished and would ask me to be his wife: an expectation, not the less certain because unexpressed, had buoyed me up, that he would claim me at once as his own. But no hint to that effect escaping him and his countenance becoming more overcast, I suddenly remembered that I might have been all wrong, and was perhaps playing the fool unwittingly; and I began gently to withdraw myself from his arms—but he eagerly snatched me closer.
“No—no—Jane; you must not go. No—I have touched you, heard you, felt the comfort of your presence—the sweetness of your consolation: I cannot give up these joys. I have little left in myself—I must have you. The world may laugh—may call me absurd, selfish—but it does not signify. My very soul demands you: it will be satisfied, or it will take deadly vengeance on its frame.”
“Well, sir, I will stay with you: I have said so.”
“Yes—but you understand one thing by staying with me; and I understand another. You, perhaps, could make up your mind to be about my hand and chair—to wait on me as a kind little nurse (for you have an affectionate heart and a generous spirit, which prompt you to make sacrifices for those you pity), and that ought to suffice for me no doubt. I suppose I should now entertain none but fatherly feelings for you: do you think so? Come—tell me.”
“I will think what you like, sir: I am content to be only your nurse, if you think it better.”
“But you cannot always be my nurse, Janet: you are young—you must marry one day.”
“I don’t care about being married.”
“You should care, Janet: if I were what I once was, I would try to make you care—but—a sightless block!”
He relapsed again into gloom. I, on the contrary, became more cheerful, and took fresh courage: these last words gave me an insight as to where the difficulty lay; and as it was no difficulty with me, I felt quite relieved from my previous embarrassment. I resumed a livelier vein of conversation.
“It is time some one undertook to rehumanise you,” said I, parting his thick and long uncut locks; “for I see you are being metamorphosed into a lion, or something of that sort. You have a ‘faux air’ of Nebuchadnezzar in the fields about you, that is certain: your hair reminds me of eagles’ feathers; whether your nails are grown like birds’ claws or not, I have not yet noticed.”
“On this arm, I have neither hand nor nails,” he said, drawing the mutilated limb from his breast, and showing it to me. “It is a mere stump—a ghastly sight! Don’t you think so, Jane?”
“It is a pity to see it; and a pity to see your eyes—and the scar of fire on your forehead: and the worst of it is, one is in danger of loving you too well for all this; and making too much of you.”
“I thought you would be revolted, Jane, when you saw my arm, and my cicatrised visage.”
“Did you? Don’t tell me so—lest I should say something disparaging to your judgment. Now, let me leave you an instant, to make a better fire, and have the hearth swept up. Can you tell when there is a good fire?”
“Yes; with the right eye I see a glow—a ruddy haze.”
“And you see the candles?”
“Very dimly—each is a luminous cloud.”
“Can you see me?”
“No, my fairy: but I am only too thankful to hear and feel you.”
“When do you take supper?”
“I never take supper.”
“But you shall have some to-night. I am hungry: so are you, I daresay, only you forget.”
Summoning Mary, I soon had the room in more cheerful order: I prepared him, likewise, a comfortable repast. My spirits were excited, and with pleasure and ease I talked to him during supper, and for a long time after. There was no harassing restraint, no repressing of glee and vivacity with him; for with him I was at perfect ease, because I knew I suited him; all I said or did seemed either to console or revive him. Delightful consciousness! It brought to life and light my whole nature: in his presence I thoroughly lived; and he lived in mine. Blind as he was, smiles played over his face, joy dawned on his forehead: his lineaments softened and warmed.

I felt a little embarrassed. The nature of the silence was embarrassing; and besides, I was what is called in folklore a “love-lorn” lass. I dallied with his hand which lay inert in mine; I chafed it palm, back, and fingers; I bent down and kissed it. Then I asked—“Will you take me back, Mr. Rochester?”

He thought I referred to the governess’s place, and said, “Don’t mention it! The memory of the past is intolerable.”

“I don’t mean that, sir. I ask if you will be my master again? If you will employ me?”

“For what, Jane? For what?”

“For anything.”

“You are poor, Jane?”

“Yes, sir.”

“And have no relations?”

“None.”

“Some one you see must have been kind to you?”

“Yes; St. John Rivers has been very kind to me.”

“You have spoken of him often: do you like him?”

“He is a very good man, sir; I could not help liking him.”

“A good man? Does that mean a respectable, well-conducted man of fifty? Or a youthful saint?”

“He is a young man, but a clergyman.”

“In what capacity has he been kind to you?”

“He has offered me marriage.”

“You have refused him?”

“I have.”

“That was right, my girl.”

“I am sure it was. Were I to marry him, my heart would bleed to death in the tears I should be forced to shed over it.”

“That is well. Jane, you would not be happy with him?”

“Never.”

“Then you could not make him happy?”

“Impossible.”

“You have a friendship for him, though?”

“Yes, sir.”

“What is he like? What does he do?”

“He is a parson—a missionary. He is going to India.”

“Goes to India! He is leaving England, then?”

“Yes.”

“Thank God! I had a dread of him.”

“What for, sir?”

“I don’t know—I don’t know. I felt a presentiment that you would be torn from me by him. Just as I have you, Jane, and see you, and listen to you, and feel you, I could fancy some right of property he had acquired in you—some power he had obtained over you, would be exercised to drag you off.”

“No, no, sir! Be at rest! No man has any power over me but you, so long as you are true to me. No one can take me from you.”

“But as you are young, Jane, and must marry some day.”

“I don’t mean to marry.”

“You don’t mean to marry! You have just said you refused St. John for love of me. And now you say you don’t mean to marry at all. That is nonsense. If I were what I once was, I would try to make you care for me—but—a sightless block!”

He relapsed again into gloom. I, on the contrary, became more cheerful, and took fresh courage: these last words gave me an insight as to where the difficulty lay; and as it was no difficulty with me, I felt quite relieved from my previous embarrassment. I took a book from the window-seat, and sat down near him. I said—

“If you won’t let me live with you, I can build a house for myself close up to your gates, and you may send me a piece of bread and a draught of water every day.”

“But you can’t live on bread and water: you must have meat and drink, and clothing and shelter. I have not the right to expect you to sacrifice your life for my sake. You are not my wife, nor ever will be. You are young—go and be happy in your own way.”

“I am happy where I am.”

“But you must get on with the world, Jane. You are suited for it—fit

events.title: Rochester's Lingering Doubts and Jane's Playful Reassurance
detailed_summary: Following supper, Rochester begins to ask Jane numerous questions about her whereabouts and activities during her absence, and how she found him, but Jane provides only brief answers, deeming it too late for detailed explanations.

He exhibits ongoing anxiety, frequently touching her as if to confirm her physical presence, and voices his deep-seated fear that she is an illusion who might disappear, describing his current happiness with her as a fragile 'enchantment.'
He recounts the months of profound despair he endured, emphasizing that his longing for her return surpassed even his desire for the restoration of his sight.
Jane employs practical observations and gentle teasing to ground him, such as noting his scorched eyebrows and offering to comb his unkempt hair.
She playfully likens his appearance to a mischievous household spirit, to which he retorts about her own impertinent nature not having diminished.
Jane further teases him by mentioning the good, refined people she has been with, successfully piquing his curiosity about her experiences.
She deliberately withholds the full account of her story until the next day, suggesting it as a reason for her certain return at breakfast, a playful tactic to assure him of her continued presence.
Rochester acknowledges her unique ability to lift his spirits, comparing her influence to that of David's harp on Saul.
As Jane prepares to retire for the night, Rochester pointedly and with underlying concern asks if there were only ladies present in the house where she had been staying.
Jane laughs at his question and makes her escape upstairs, pleased with herself for discovering a means to playfully challenge and distract him from his melancholy.

events.text_segment:
After supper, he began to ask me many questions, of where I had been, what I had been doing, how I had found him out; but I gave him only very partial replies: it was too late to enter into particulars that night. Besides, I wished to touch no deep-thrilling chord—to open no fresh well of emotion in his heart: my sole present aim was to cheer him. Cheered, as I have said, he was: and yet but by fits. If a moment’s silence broke the conversation, he would turn restless, touch me, then say, “Jane.”
“You are altogether a human being, Jane? You are certain of that?”
“I conscientiously believe so, Mr. Rochester.”
“Yet how, on this dark and doleful evening, could you so suddenly rise on my lone hearth? I stretched my hand to take a glass of water from a hireling, and it was given me by you: I asked a question, expecting John’s wife to answer me, and your voice spoke at my ear.”
“Because I had come in, in Mary’s stead, with the tray.”
“And there is enchantment in the very hour I am now spending with you. Who can tell what a dark, dreary, hopeless life I have dragged on for months past? Doing nothing, expecting nothing; merging night in day; feeling but the sensation of cold when I let the fire go out, of hunger when I forgot to eat: and then a ceaseless sorrow, and, at times, a very delirium of desire to behold my Jane again. Yes: for her restoration I longed, far more than for that of my lost sight. How can it be that Jane is with me, and says she loves me? Will she not depart as suddenly as she came? To-morrow, I fear I shall find her no more.”
A commonplace, practical reply, out of the train of his own disturbed ideas, was, I was sure, the best and most reassuring for him in this frame of mind. I passed my finger over his eyebrows, and remarked that they were scorched, and that I would apply something which would make them grow as broad and black as ever.
“Where is the use of doing me good in any way, beneficent spirit, when, at some fatal moment, you will again desert me—passing like a shadow, whither and how to me unknown, and for me remaining afterwards undiscoverable?”
“Have you a pocket-comb about you, sir?”
“What for, Jane?”
“Just to comb out this shaggy black mane. I find you rather alarming, when I examine you close at hand: you talk of my being a fairy, but I am sure, you are more like a brownie.”
“Am I hideous, Jane?”
“Very, sir: you always were, you know.”
“Humph! The wickedness has not been taken out of you, wherever you have sojourned.”
“Yet I have been with good people; far better than you: a hundred times better people; possessed of ideas and views you never entertained in your life: quite more refined and exalted.”
“Who the deuce have you been with?”
“If you twist in that way you will make me pull the hair out of your head; and then I think you will cease to entertain doubts of my substantiality.”
“Who have you been with, Jane?”
“You shall not get it out of me to-night, sir; you must wait till to-morrow; to leave my tale half told, will, you know, be a sort of security that I shall appear at your breakfast table to finish it. By the bye, I must mind not to rise on your hearth with only a glass of water then: I must bring an egg at the least, to say nothing of fried ham.”
“You mocking changeling—fairy-born and human-bred! You make me feel as I have not felt these twelve months. If Saul could have had you for his David, the evil spirit would have been exorcised without the aid of the harp.”
“There, sir, you are redd up and made decent. Now I’ll leave you: I have been travelling these last three days, and I believe I am tired. Good night.”
“Just one word, Jane: were there only ladies in the house where you have been?”
I laughed and made my escape, still laughing as I ran upstairs. “A good idea!” I thought with glee. “I see I have the means of fretting him out of his melancholy for some time to come.”

{
  "text_segment": "After supper, he began to ask me many questions, of where I had been, what I had been doing, how I had found him out; but I gave him only very partial replies: it was too late to enter into particulars that night. Besides, I wished to touch him, to see him, to be with him too long, to permit explanations to occupy the brief time I had at my disposal. He was still holding my hand, and he pressed it softly every now and then. 

"Her presence is enchantment," he said, as if speaking to himself. "She is not of flesh and blood; she is a spirit. Oh, I have been tormented! I have been haunted for months, Jane! I have longed for you, both with soul and flesh! I have asked God, with constant prayers, that I might see you again. I have followed you in my dreams, and I have called your name in my sleep. I have had a strange, persistent feeling that you were near me, and that you would come back to me. I am not sure of the reality of your presence. You are a dream, a vision that will vanish when I wake."

"No, sir," I said, "I am not a dream. I am Jane Eyre: I have found you out—I am come back to you."

"In truth?—in the flesh? My living Jane?"

"You touch me, sir,—you hold my hand, you see my cloak and bonnet: do you still doubt?"

"I do, I do. My sight is gone, Jane; my heart is broken. My mind has been a chaos of misery and despair. I have longed for you more than I have longed for sight. To have you back is to have my hope and my life restored."

"Then, sir, for the present, at least, you are satisfied; for you have me. And now, let me look at you. Your eyebrows are singed; your hair is rough and uncombed."

"Singed and rough, are they? Well, I have no one to attend to me. Let me have a comb and a brush."

"You are not grown correcter, are you, Jane?"

"I think you are a little worse than you were, on the whole; you are so very grim and cynical. You look like a certain Irish myth, the Gytrash in person. But I will not be your English slave. I will manage you. I will comb your hair for you."

"And you will not leave me? You will stay with me?"

"Certainly—I will be your neighbour, your nurse, your housekeeper. I find you lonely: I will be your companion—to read to you, to walk with you, to sit with you, to wait on you, to be eyes and hands to you. Cease to look so melancholy, my dear master; you shall not be left desolate, so long as I live."

He approved of my intentions, and I proceeded to fulfil them. I combed his hair and arranged it to my liking. I then asked him what he had been doing during my absence.

"Doing! I have been suffering. But I will not complain. I have deserved it all. I have been with good people; far better, far more refined than you think me. You may be sure of that.\

events.title: Morning Realities and Deepening Connection Outdoors
detailed_summary: Very early the next morning, Jane hears Rochester restless and moving about, and soon after Mary comes down, he eagerly inquires about Miss Eyre's presence, her room, and when she will come down.

Jane descends when she anticipates breakfast, and observes Rochester before he is aware of her presence, noting with sorrow the subjugation of his once vigorous spirit to his physical infirmities; he sits expectantly, his features marked by habitual sadness.
His countenance reminds her of a quenched lamp waiting to be relit by another's hand, a realization that deeply touches her.
Despite her intention to be gay and careless, she accosts him with as much vivacity as she can muster, announcing a bright, sunny morning and promising him a walk soon.

Her words instantly illuminate his features; he expresses immense joy and relief at her confirmed presence, likening her voice to a skylark's song and stating that all melody and sunshine for him are now concentrated in her.
Jane is moved to tears by this candid admission of his dependence but quickly composes herself and busies herself with preparing breakfast.
They spend a significant portion of the morning outdoors, with Jane leading him from the damp wood into cheerful fields.
She vividly describes the brilliant green of the fields, the refreshed appearance of flowers and hedges, and the sparkling blue sky.
She finds a comfortable seat for him on a dry tree stump in a secluded spot and willingly sits on his knee when he draws her there, acknowledging their mutual happiness in closeness.
Pilot, the dog, lies quietly beside them, enhancing the peaceful atmosphere.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Very early the next morning I heard him up and astir, wandering from one room to another.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Pilot lay beside us: all was quiet.

events.text_segment:
Very early the next morning I heard him up and astir, wandering from one room to another. As soon as Mary came down I heard the question: “Is Miss Eyre here?” Then: “Which room did you put her into? Was it dry? Is she up? Go and ask if she wants anything; and when she will come down.”
I came down as soon as I thought there was a prospect of breakfast. Entering the room very softly, I had a view of him before he discovered my presence. It was mournful, indeed, to witness the subjugation of that vigorous spirit to a corporeal infirmity. He sat in his chair—still, but not at rest: expectant evidently; the lines of now habitual sadness marking his strong features. His countenance reminded one of a lamp quenched, waiting to be re-lit—and alas! it was not himself that could now kindle the lustre of animated expression: he was dependent on another for that office! I had meant to be gay and careless, but the powerlessness of the strong man touched my heart to the quick: still I accosted him with what vivacity I could.
“It is a bright, sunny morning, sir,” I said. “The rain is over and gone, and there is a tender shining after it: you shall have a walk soon.”
I had wakened the glow: his features beamed.
“Oh, you are indeed there, my skylark! Come to me. You are not gone: not vanished? I heard one of your kind an hour ago, singing high over the wood: but its song had no music for me, any more than the rising sun had rays. All the melody on earth is concentrated in my Jane’s tongue to my ear (I am glad it is not naturally a silent one): all the sunshine I can feel is in her presence.”
The water stood in my eyes to hear this avowal of his dependence; just as if a royal eagle, chained to a perch, should be forced to entreat a sparrow to become its purveyor. But I would not be lachrymose: I dashed off the salt drops, and busied myself with preparing breakfast.
Most of the morning was spent in the open air. I led him out of the wet and wild wood into some cheerful fields: I described to him how brilliantly green they were; how the flowers and hedges looked refreshed; how sparklingly blue was the sky. I sought a seat for him in a hidden and lovely spot, a dry stump of a tree; nor did I refuse to let him, when seated, place me on his knee. Why should I, when both he and I were happier near than apart? Pilot lay beside us: all was quiet.

events.title: Rochester's Past Anguish and Jane's Abridged Story
detailed_summary: While they are sitting together outdoors, Rochester suddenly clasps Jane and vehemently expresses the profound anguish he experienced when he discovered her flight from Thornfield, particularly his distress upon realizing she had taken no money or valuables.
He describes finding her pearl necklace untouched and her trunks still locked, and his torment wondering what had become of his destitute and penniless 'darling.'
He earnestly urges Jane to recount what happened to her.
Prompted by his plea, Jane begins the narrative of her experiences over the past year.

She significantly softens the details of her three days of wandering and starvation, wishing to avoid inflicting unnecessary pain on him, though the little she does reveal deeply wounds his faithful heart.
Rochester passionately declares that she should not have left him in such a manner, without any means of support, and that she should have confided her intentions to him.

He asserts that, despite his desperate behavior, his love for her was too profound and tender for him to have ever made her his mistress against her will; he would have preferred to give her half his fortune rather than see her cast friendless upon the world.
He expresses certainty that she endured far more suffering than she has admitted.

Jane downplays her past hardships as brief and then proceeds to tell him about her reception at Moor House by St. John Rivers and his sisters, her work as a schoolmistress, her subsequent inheritance, and the discovery of her familial relations.
Throughout her account, St. John Rivers' name is mentioned frequently, setting the stage for Rochester's subsequent inquiries.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He broke out suddenly while clasping me in his arms—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When I had done, that name was immediately taken up.

events.text_segment:
He broke out suddenly while clasping me in his arms—
“Cruel, cruel deserter! Oh, Jane, what did I feel when I discovered you had fled from Thornfield, and when I could nowhere find you; and, after examining your apartment, ascertained that you had taken no money, nor anything which could serve as an equivalent! A pearl necklace I had given you lay untouched in its little casket; your trunks were left corded and locked as they had been prepared for the bridal tour. What could my darling do, I asked, left destitute and penniless? And what did she do? Let me hear now.”
Thus urged, I began the narrative of my experience for the last year. I softened considerably what related to the three days of wandering and starvation, because to have told him all would have been to inflict unnecessary pain: the little I did say lacerated his faithful heart deeper than I wished.
I should not have left him thus, he said, without any means of making my way: I should have told him my intention. I should have confided in him: he would never have forced me to be his mistress. Violent as he had seemed in his despair, he, in truth, loved me far too well and too tenderly to constitute himself my tyrant: he would have given me half his fortune, without demanding so much as a kiss in return, rather than I should have flung myself friendless on the wide world. I had endured, he was certain, more than I had confessed to him.
“Well, whatever my sufferings had been, they were very short,” I answered: and then I proceeded to tell him how I had been received at Moor House; how I had obtained the office of schoolmistress, &c. The accession of fortune, the discovery of my relations, followed in due order. Of course, St. John Rivers’ name came in frequently in the progress of my tale. When I had done, that name was immediately taken up.

events.title: Rochester's Spiraling Jealousy over St. John
detailed_summary: Immediately after Jane finishes her narrative, Rochester focuses intently on St. John Rivers, confirming that he is Jane's cousin.
He asks Jane if she likes St. John, to which she responds affirmatively, calling him a very good man.
Rochester then attempts to diminish St. John, questioning if 'good man' implies someone elderly and unexciting, or otherwise unremarkable.
Jane corrects Rochester's assumptions, stating that St. John is only twenty-nine, tirelessly active, and dedicated to performing great and exalted deeds.
Still skeptical, Rochester probes further, insinuating that St. John's intellect might be weak or his conversation uninspiring.
Jane counters by praising St. John's first-rate, vigorous mind and his concise, pointed manner of speaking, affirming he is an able man.
She confirms that St. John is a thoroughly educated, accomplished, and profound scholar.

When Rochester inquires about his manners, suggesting they might be priggish or parsonic, Jane states she never mentioned them but believes they would suit any good taste, being polished, calm, and gentlemanlike.
Rochester then sarcastically mischaracterizes St. John's appearance, painting a picture of an awkward, poorly dressed curate.
Jane provides a clear and favorable description: St. John dresses well and is handsome, tall, fair, with blue eyes and a Grecian profile.
Upon hearing this, Rochester quietly expresses his extreme displeasure about St. John, then directly asks Jane again, with pointed emphasis, if she liked him.

Jane confirms that she did like St. John, acknowledging to herself that she understands the jealous direction of Rochester's questioning, which she views as a beneficial distraction from his deeper melancholy.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I would not, therefore, immediately charm the snake.

events.text_segment:
This St. John, then, is your cousin?”
“Yes.”
“You have spoken of him often: do you like him?”
“He was a very good man, sir; I could not help liking him.”
“A good man. Does that mean a respectable well-conducted man of fifty? Or what does it mean?”
“St John was only twenty-nine, sir.”
“‘Jeune encore,’ as the French say. Is he a person of low stature, phlegmatic, and plain? A person whose goodness consists rather in his guiltlessness of vice, than in his prowess in virtue.”
“He is untiringly active. Great and exalted deeds are what he lives to perform.”
“But his brain? That is probably rather soft? He means well: but you shrug your shoulders to hear him talk?”
“He talks little, sir: what he does say is ever to the point. His brain is first-rate, I should think not impressible, but vigorous.”
“Is he an able man, then?”
“Truly able.”
“A thoroughly educated man?”
“St. John is an accomplished and profound scholar.”
“His manners, I think, you said are not to your taste?—priggish and parsonic?”
“I never mentioned his manners; but, unless I had a very bad taste, they must suit it; they are polished, calm, and gentlemanlike.”
“His appearance,—I forget what description you gave of his appearance;—a sort of raw curate, half strangled with his white neckcloth, and stilted up on his thick-soled high-lows, eh?”
“St. John dresses well. He is a handsome man: tall, fair, with blue eyes, and a Grecian profile.”
(Aside.) “Damn him!”—(To me.) “Did you like him, Jane?”
“Yes, Mr. Rochester, I liked him: but you asked me that before.”
I perceived, of course, the drift of my interlocutor. Jealousy had got hold of him: she stung him; but the sting was salutary: it gave him respite from the gnawing fang of melancholy. I would not, therefore, immediately charm the snake.

events.title: The "Cross-Examination," Revelation of Truth, and Joyful Proposal
detailed_summary: Feeling the stark contrast between Jane's flattering description of St. John and his own physically diminished state, Rochester suggests, with some bitterness, that Jane might no longer wish to sit on his knee.

He then initiates a detailed 'cross-examination' regarding the nature and frequency of her interactions with St. John, inquiring about his visits to her school and cottage, and the evenings he might have spent there.

Rochester meticulously questions her about the five months she resided with St. John and his sisters after the discovery of their kinship, focusing on St. John's studies (Hindostanee) and what Jane herself learned during that time.
Jane reveals that St. John taught her Hindostanee, and specifically only her, because he wished her to learn it.
When Rochester presses her for St. John's motive, Jane admits that he intended for her to accompany him to India and had asked her to marry him.
Rochester initially dismisses this as a malicious invention designed to upset him, but Jane calmly insists on its literal truth, adding that St. John was quite persistent.
Agitated, Rochester again tells Jane she can leave him, accusing her heart of being with St. John and lamenting the bitter thought that while he mourned her, she was loving another.
Jane firmly refuses to leave of her own will, and Rochester, momentarily softened by the truthfulness in her tone, admits it renews his hope.

She then decisively clarifies her relationship with St. John: he is not, and never will be, her husband, as he does not love her (his affections being for Rosamond) and she does not love him, finding him good and great but also severe and, for her, emotionally cold.

Immensely relieved, Rochester asks if this is truly the state of matters. Jane confirms it, confessing she had teased him a little to alleviate his sadness, believing anger preferable to grief, and then passionately declares her complete and unwavering love for him.

Despite her reassurances, painful thoughts of his 'seared vision' and 'crippled strength' resurface for Rochester, and he mournfully compares himself to the old lightning-struck chestnut-tree at Thornfield.
Jane vehemently rejects this self-deprecating analogy, asserting that he is still green and vigorous, a strong tree around which other plants (friends, and more) will naturally lean and flourish.
When he asks if she speaks of friends, she hesitates, meaning more. Rochester then directly states his own desire: he wants a wife.
He asks Jane to make the choice of a wife for him; she advises him to select the one who holds the deepest affection for him.
Rochester declares he will select the one he himself loves most profoundly, and then directly asks Jane if she will marry him.
Without hesitation, Jane joyfully says 'Yes, sir,' affirming her willingness to marry him despite his blindness, physical limitations, and the twenty-year age difference.
Rochester, overcome, blesses her. Jane expresses that becoming his wife is the greatest happiness she can achieve on earth, viewing it not as a sacrifice but as the fulfillment of all she values.
She reframes her commitment as gaining nourishment for famine and contentment for expectation, privileged to embrace what she loves and trust.
Rochester acknowledges her willingness to bear his infirmities, and Jane asserts that his deficiencies are none to her, loving him better now in his dependency than in his former proud independence.
He admits he will no longer hate being helped, finding joy in her care. They affirm their profound mutual suitability.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: To the finest fibre of my nature, sir.”

events.text_segment:
Perhaps you would rather not sit any longer on my knee, Miss Eyre?” was the next somewhat unexpected observation.
“Why not, Mr. Rochester?”
“The picture you have just drawn is suggestive of a rather too overwhelming contrast. Your words have delineated very prettily a graceful Apollo: he is present to your imagination,—tall, fair, blue-eyed, and with a Grecian profile. Your eyes dwell on a Vulcan,—a real blacksmith, brown, broad-shouldered: and blind and lame into the bargain.”
“I never thought of it, before; but you certainly are rather like Vulcan, sir.”
“Well, you can leave me, ma’am: but before you go” (and he retained me by a firmer grasp than ever), “you will be pleased just to answer me a question or two.” He paused.
“What questions, Mr. Rochester?”
Then followed this cross-examination.
“St. John made you schoolmistress of Morton before he knew you were his cousin?”
“Yes.”
“You would often see him? He would visit the school sometimes?”
“Daily.”
“He would approve of your plans, Jane? I know they would be clever, for you are a talented creature!”
“He approved of them—yes.”
“He would discover many things in you he could not have expected to find? Some of your accomplishments are not ordinary.”
“I don’t know about that.”
“You had a little cottage near the school, you say: did he ever come there to see you?”
“Now and then.”
“Of an evening?”
“Once or twice.”
A pause.
“How long did you reside with him and his sisters after the cousinship was discovered?”
“Five months.”
“Did Rivers spend much time with the ladies of his family?”
“Yes; the back parlour was both his study and ours: he sat near the window, and we by the table.”
“Did he study much?”
“A good deal.”
“What?”
“Hindostanee.”
“And what did you do meantime?”
“I learnt German, at first.”
“Did he teach you?”
“He did not understand German.”
“Did he teach you nothing?”
“A little Hindostanee.”
“Rivers taught you Hindostanee?”
“Yes, sir.”
“And his sisters also?”
“No.”
“Only you?”
“Only me.”
“Did you ask to learn?”
“No.”
“He wished to teach you?”
“Yes.”
A second pause.
“Why did he wish it? Of what use could Hindostanee be to you?”
“He intended me to go with him to India.”
“Ah! here I reach the root of the matter. He wanted you to marry him?”
“He asked me to marry him.”
“That is a fiction—an impudent invention to vex me.”
“I beg your pardon, it is the literal truth: he asked me more than once, and was as stiff about urging his point as ever you could be.”
“Miss Eyre, I repeat it, you can leave me. How often am I to say the same thing? Why do you remain pertinaciously perched on my knee, when I have given you notice to quit?”
“Because I am comfortable there.”
“No, Jane, you are not comfortable there, because your heart is not with me: it is with this cousin—this St. John. Oh, till this moment, I thought my little Jane was all mine! I had a belief she loved me even when she left me: that was an atom of sweet in much bitter. Long as we have been parted, hot tears as I have wept over our separation, I never thought that while I was mourning her, she was loving another! But it is useless grieving. Jane, leave me: go and marry Rivers.”
“Shake me off, then, sir,—push me away, for I’ll not leave you of my own accord.”
“Jane, I ever like your tone of voice: it still renews hope, it sounds so truthful. When I hear it, it carries me back a year. I forget that you have formed a new tie. But I am not a fool—go—”
“Where must I go, sir?”
“Your own way—with the husband you have chosen.”
“Who is that?”
“You know—this St. John Rivers.”
“He is not my husband, nor ever will be. He does not love me: I do not love him. He loves (as he can love, and that is not as you love) a beautiful young lady called Rosamond. He wanted to marry me only because he thought I should make a suitable missionary’s wife, which she would not have done. He is good and great, but severe; and, for me, cold as an iceberg. He is not like you, sir: I am not happy at his side, nor near him, nor with him. He has no indulgence for me—no fondness. He sees nothing attractive in me; not even youth—only a few useful mental points.—Then I must leave you, sir, to go to him?”
I shuddered involuntarily, and clung instinctively closer to my blind but beloved master. He smiled.
“What, Jane! Is this true? Is such really the state of matters between you and Rivers?”
“Absolutely, sir! Oh, you need not be jealous! I wanted to tease you a little to make you less sad: I thought anger would be better than grief. But if you wish me to love you, could you but see how much I do love you, you would be proud and content. All my heart is yours, sir: it belongs to you; and with you it would remain, were fate to exile the rest of me from your presence for ever.”
Again, as he kissed me, painful thoughts darkened his aspect.
“My seared vision! My crippled strength!” he murmured regretfully.
I caressed, in order to soothe him. I knew of what he was thinking, and wanted to speak for him, but dared not. As he turned aside his face a minute, I saw a tear slide from under the sealed eyelid, and trickle down the manly cheek. My heart swelled.
“I am no better than the old lightning-struck chestnut-tree in Thornfield orchard,” he remarked ere long. “And what right would that ruin have to bid a budding woodbine cover its decay with freshness?”
“You are no ruin, sir—no lightning-struck tree: you are green and vigorous. Plants will grow about your roots, whether you ask them or not, because they take delight in your bountiful shadow; and as they grow they will lean towards you, and wind round you, because your strength offers them so safe a prop.”
Again he smiled: I gave him comfort.
“You speak of friends, Jane?” he asked.
“Yes, of friends,” I answered rather hesitatingly: for I knew I meant more than friends, but could not tell what other word to employ. He helped me.
“Ah! Jane. But I want a wife.”
“Do you, sir?”
“Yes: is it news to you?”
“Of course: you said nothing about it before.”
“Is it unwelcome news?”
“That depends on circumstances, sir—on your choice.”
“Which you shall make for me, Jane. I will abide by your decision.”
“Choose then, sir—her who loves you best.”
“I will at least choose—her I love best. Jane, will you marry me?”
“Yes, sir.”
“A poor blind man, whom you will have to lead about by the hand?”
“Yes, sir.”
“A crippled man, twenty years older than you, whom you will have to wait on?”
“Yes, sir.”
“Truly, Jane?”
“Most truly, sir.”
“Oh! my darling! God bless you and reward you!”
“Mr. Rochester, if ever I did a good deed in my life—if ever I thought a good thought—if ever I prayed a sincere and blameless prayer—if ever I wished a righteous wish,—I am rewarded now. To be your wife is, for me, to be as happy as I can be on earth.”
“Because you delight in sacrifice.”
“Sacrifice! What do I sacrifice? Famine for food, expectation for content. To be privileged to put my arms round what I value—to press my lips to what I love—to repose on what I trust: is that to make a sacrifice? If so, then certainly I delight in sacrifice.”
“And to bear with my infirmities, Jane: to overlook my deficiencies.”
“Which are none, sir, to me. I love you better now, when I can really be useful to you, than I did in your state of proud independence, when you disdained every part but that of the giver and protector.”
“Hitherto I have hated to be helped—to be led: henceforth, I feel I shall hate it no more. I did not like to put my hand into a hireling’s, but it is pleasant to feel it circled by Jane’s little fingers. I preferred utter loneliness to the constant attendance of servants; but Jane’s soft ministry will be a perpetual joy. Jane suits me: do I suit her?”
“To the finest fibre of my nature, sir.”

Perhaps you would rather not sit any longer on my knee, Miss Eyre?” was the next somewhat unexpected observation.

“Why not, Mr. Rochester?”

“The fact is, I am a trifle beside myself. I was waiting for you to tell me about St. John Rivers.”

“He has not forgotten you, then?”

“I believe he is a man who never forgets. What did he say of me? Tell me.”

“He spoke of you, sir, as an old friend.”

“I see. You have not told him, then, of your discovery?”

“A month ago I wrote to him and gave him an account of the circumstances, touching upon the argument which had weakened his sight and crippled his hand.”

“I see. Not a word to St. John of the relations between us?”

“I was not sure what they were. You had not spoken to me for a week.”

“I had not dared to speak to you,” he returned. “I was in no condition to do so. I felt myself a mere wreck.”

“But you are better now?”

“Yes, a little better.”

“I am glad of it.”

“And you, Jane?” he asked, turning his head towards me. “You are not turning your thoughts to St. John Rivers now? You are not considering in your own mind the possibility of a union with him?”

“No, sir; never.”

“That is well. But I must have a little more information. Be so good as to sit still a little longer. How did you get on with St. John Rivers, after I left you? What was he like? What did he say to you?”

“He was a very good man, sir; I could not have had a better friend.”

“How did you get on with him? Did he visit you at your school?”

“He came once a week.”

“A good-looking man, Jane?”

“Very, sir.”

“A young man?”

“He is about my own age—twenty-nine.”

“Is he a man of fortune?”

“Not by inheritance, but he has a good living in his own gift.”

“In his own gift? Indeed! That is more than I can say of myself. And what did you think of him, Jane?”

“I thought him a very good man, sir.”

“You are sure of that?”

“I am sure.”

“And what did he think of you? What did he say about you?”

“He said I was a good girl.”

“Indeed! And what did you say to him?”

“I said I was glad he thought so.”

“You are a little story-teller,” he said, with a smile. “But I will not press you. I will get it all out of you by-and-by. And so you have been living with him and his sisters ever since?”

“Yes, sir.”

“And you have been happy with them?”

“Very happy.”

“And you have no wish to leave them?”

“I have a wish to leave them, but not to leave them for ever.”

“And what is your wish?”

“My wish is to be with you.”

“Indeed! You have a strange way of showing it. You have been away from me for a whole year.”

“I could not come back, sir.”

“Why not?”

“Because I was not sure that you would be glad to see me.”

“And you are sure now?”

“I am sure.”

“How are you sure?”

“Because you have told me so.”

“And you believe me?”

“I do.”

“You are a little sorceress,” he said. “But I will not be bewitched. I will have the whole truth out of you. What have you been doing with yourself all this time? What have you been learning?”

“I have been learning to be a schoolmistress.”

“Indeed! And what have you learned besides?”

“I have learned to speak Hindostanee.”

“The devil you have!” he exclaimed. “And who taught you?”

“St. John Rivers.”

“And what did he teach you that for?”

“He wished me to go with him to India.”

“The deuce he did! And what for?”

“To be his wife.”

“I will, sir. It is the literal truth. He asked me to marry him.”

“And you refused him?”

“I did.”

“You refused him! And why?”

“Because I did not love him.”

“You did not love him! And he—did he love you?”

“He did not love me, sir; he only thought I should make a suitable wife for a missionary.”

And you, Jane, you are a little fool for listening to him. But I forgive you. I forgive you everything. I know you have been tried. I know you have been tempted. But you have resisted. You have come back to me. You are my own Jane still.”

He drew me to him, and kissed me again and again. I could not speak for weeping.

“Now, Jane,” he said, as he released me, “you must not cry. You must be my comforter. You must be my right hand. You must be my eyes. You must be my everything. And you will be, will you not?”

“I will, sir; I will.”

“And you will not leave me again?”

“Never, sir; never.”

“Then we will be married at once.”

“Yes, sir.”

“And we will live here at Ferndean. It is a quiet place, and we shall be happy here.”

“Yes, sir.”

“And you will not mind my being blind?”

“No, sir; I shall be your guide.”

“And you will not mind my being a cripple?”

“No, sir; I shall be your nurse.”

“And you will not mind my being twenty years older than you?”

“No, sir; I shall be your companion.”

“And you will love me, Jane?”

“Yes, sir; I will love you with all my heart and soul.”

And you, Jane, you are a little fool for listening to him. But I forgive you. I forgive you everything. I know you have been tried. I know you have been tempted. But you have resisted. You have come back to me. You are my own Jane still.”

He drew me to him, and kissed me again and again. I could not speak for weeping.

“Now, Jane,” he said, as he released me, “you must not cry. You must be my comforter. You must be my right hand. You must be my eyes. You must be my everything. And you will be, will you not?”

“I will, sir; I will.”

“And you will not leave me again?”

“Never, sir; never.”

“Then we will be married at once.”

“Yes, sir.”

“And we will live here at Ferndean. It is a quiet place, and we shall be happy here.”

“Yes, sir.”

“And you will not mind my being blind?”

“No, sir; I shall be your guide.”

“And you will not mind my being a cripple?”

“No, sir; I shall be your nurse.”

“And you will not mind my being twenty years older than you?”

“No, sir; I shall be your companion.”

“And you will love me, Jane?”

“Yes, sir; I will love you with all my heart and soul.”

“Then, God bless you, my own Jane! I have found my

events.title: Impending Marriage, Spiritual Reflections, and a Shared Supernatural Connection
detailed_summary: Convinced of their mutual suitability, Rochester, with his old impetuosity surging, insists they must marry immediately, setting the wedding day for the third day from then.
He dismisses any concern for fine clothes or jewels, considering them trivial, and gives Jane his watch, stating he no longer has use for it.
He reveals to Jane that he has been wearing her small pearl necklace, a memento of his 'only treasure,' since the day he lost her.
Rochester then expresses profound gratitude to God, reflecting on his past transgressions and acknowledging the divine justice in his subsequent suffering, which ultimately humbled him.

He confesses that only recently, he began to recognize God's hand in his fate, experiencing remorse, repentance, and a desire for reconciliation with his Maker, leading him to offer brief but sincere prayers.

He recounts a specific, singular experience from the previous Monday night, four days prior. Believing Jane to be dead and in deep despair, he had supplicated God for his own life to end so he might rejoin her in the afterlife.
In his anguish, he had cried out Jane's name multiple times with frantic energy.
Jane inquires if he spoke these words aloud, and he confirms he did, with such intensity that any listener would have thought him mad.

Rochester then describes the strange event that followed: he heard a voice, which he knew to be Jane's, reply with an assurance of her imminent arrival and an inquiry about his location. The words seemed to echo as if among distant mountains, and he felt a spiritual meeting had occurred.

Internally, Jane recognizes the profound coincidence: this was the very night, near midnight, and those were the exact words of her own mysterious summons and her response to it. However, she chooses to keep this 'awful and inexplicable' connection to herself, deeming it too prone to agitate Rochester's currently vulnerable mind with supernatural thoughts.
Rochester explains that this prior experience made him initially doubt Jane's physical return the previous night, fearing she was another ethereal voice or vision that would melt away.
He now fervently thanks God for the certainty of her real presence.

He rises from his knee, reverently lifts his hat, and, with sightless eyes bent towards the earth, stands in mute devotion, his final audible words being a prayer of thanks to his Maker for remembering mercy amidst judgment and an entreaty for strength to lead a purer life.
He then stretches out his hand, ready to be led.

Jane takes his 'dear hand,' kisses it briefly, and then allows it to rest on her shoulder, serving as both his prop and guide due to her shorter stature, as they enter the wood and walk homeward together.
